overview: Infratil is a New Zealand-based infrastructure investment company that owns and operates a diversified portfolio of 15 infrastructure assets across four key sectors: Digital Infrastructure (66%), Renewable Energy (21%), Healthcare (8%), and Airports (5%). The company operates globally with investments in 18 countries across Australasia, North America, Asia, Europe, and the UK. Infratil's strategy focuses on 'ideas that matter' - infrastructure sectors shaped by enduring social and economic trends including digitization, decarbonization, and aging populations.

business_model.summary: Infratil generates returns through a combination of capital appreciation, dividends from portfolio companies, and active portfolio management. The company is externally managed by Morrison & Co under a management agreement, targeting 11-15% annual shareholder returns over a ten-year rolling basis.

revenue_streams.name: Other investments (Kao Data, Galileo, Gurin, Mint)

business_model.customer_type: Mix of B2B (data centres, wholesale energy, telecom infrastructure) and B2C (retail telecommunications, medical imaging, airport services)
business_model.geographic_mix: New Zealand 35%, Australia 30%, United States 20%, Asia 10%, Europe/UK 5%
business_model.portfolio_structure: Three-pillar approach: Pillar 1 (cash generators: One NZ, Contact Energy, Wellington Airport), Pillar 2 (mature growth: CDC, Longroad), Pillar 3 (future growth: Gurin, Galileo, Kao Data, Mint)

competitive_position.market_position: Leading infrastructure investment company in New Zealand, NZ$10 billion market capitalization, included in MSCI Global Standard Index and ASX 200

moat_factors.description: CDC and Longroad benefit from scale in development pipelines, procurement, and financing. CDC is a top-tier data centre operator in Australasia with contracted growth
Data centre contracts typically 10-15 years, renewable energy PPAs 15-25 years, providing revenue visibility and downside protection
30+ years of infrastructure investment experience, global network of 200+ professionals, strong origination and value creation capabilities
One NZ holds spectrum licenses, Wellington Airport has monopoly position, renewable projects have development rights and grid connections
One NZ mobile customers (4 in 10 New Zealanders), data centre connectivity and power access creates competitive advantages

weaknesses: High concentration in CDC (41% of portfolio value) creates single-asset risk
New Zealand economic exposure through One NZ, Wellington Airport, and healthcare assets
External management structure incurs fees (including performance-based incentive fees)
Share price trades at discount to portfolio NAV at times
Smaller scale versus global infrastructure mega-funds

growth_drivers: AI-driven data centre demand - CDC targeting to double FY25 EBITDAF by FY27, announced 140MW of new contracts in one month (Oct 2025)
US renewable energy build-out - Longroad growing from 3.5GW to 10GW by 2028, driven by data centre power demand and clean energy transition
Energy transition megatrend - Contact Energy merger with Manawa adding 500MW capacity, Gurin's US$2-3 billion Singapore solar project (Project Vanda)
Portfolio optimization - NZ$1 billion divestment program (58% complete) to reinvest in higher-growth opportunities
Synergies between digital and renewable platforms - Longroad supplying power to data centres (1000 Mile solar project for Meta)
New growth platforms - advanced logistics, transportation/fleets, financial systems identified as potential Pillar 3 investments

business.description: CDC represents 41% of portfolio value. Overconcentration in single asset creates volatility risk and limits diversification benefits. AI demand uncertainty could impact valuations
Domestic economic headwinds affecting One NZ, Wellington Airport domestic passengers, and healthcare volumes. NZ recession would impact ~35% of portfolio
AI investment cycle uncertainty, hyperscaler capex pullbacks, or technology shifts (e.g., Deep Seek model efficiency) could slow CDC growth. Market concerns in early 2025 demonstrated sentiment risk
Changes to IRA tax credits, tariffs (Liberation Day), or renewable incentives could impact Longroad's development economics and project valuations
Air New Zealand fleet availability issues and domestic travel weakness reducing passenger volumes. Limited alternative airlines serve Wellington

financial.description: NZ$2.2 billion net debt at corporate level plus portfolio company debt. Rising rates increase funding costs and pressure infrastructure asset valuations. Higher for longer rates compress multiples
Significant AUD (CDC, Qscan, RetireAustralia) and USD (Longroad) exposure. NZD strength reduces NZD value of offshore earnings and asset values
Active refinancing in FY2025 (CDC, One NZ, Wellington Airport, Qscan) extended duration and reduced near-term risk. Strong covenant compliance across portfolio
Large committed capital programs at CDC (A$250m over next year) and Longroad (US$110m to 2027). Must balance growth investment with maintaining financial flexibility

regulatory.description: One NZ subject to Commerce Commission oversight on pricing and competition. Mobile termination rates, spectrum allocation, and infrastructure sharing rules impact economics
Wellington Airport aeronautical prices subject to Commerce Commission review. Input methodologies and price paths can limit revenue growth
Electricity market reforms in NZ, renewable incentive changes in US/Europe, and grid connection rules affect Contact, Longroad, Galileo, and Gurin
Data centre operations subject to increasing data localization, sovereignty, and privacy requirements. Could create compliance costs or operational constraints

macro.description: Economic downturn would pressure One NZ ARPU, Wellington Airport travel demand, healthcare imaging volumes, and corporate IT spending affecting CDC
Liberation Day tariffs and US trade policy changes could increase equipment costs for data centres and renewable projects, or impact customer industries
Data centre growth requires significant power availability. Grid constraints in Australia/NZ could slow CDC expansion or increase power procurement costs
Physical assets exposed to earthquakes (Wellington), cyclones, flooding. Climate change may affect hydro generation patterns and create stranded asset risk for some generation

execution.description: Gurin's US$2-3bn Project Vanda highly complex (solar in Indonesia, export to Singapore). Permitting, political, and execution risks. Single large project concentration
Large incentive fee payable to Morrison over 3 years (primarily CDC outperformance). While aligned, fees reduce net returns to shareholders. High watermark helps
Executing NZ$1bn divestment program while deploying capital to growth assets. Transaction market challenging. Asset sales can take 2-3 years
Contact-Manawa merger integration, One NZ transformation, Qscan platform rollout. Operating complexity across 15 investments in 18 countries

macro_factors.industry_outlook: Infrastructure investment benefiting from structural trends: AI driving data centre demand, energy transition driving renewables growth, government infrastructure deficits creating private capital opportunities. Global infrastructure returns expected 8-12% over cycle
macro_factors.cyclicality: Low to moderate - mix of defensive cash generators (utilities, airports, healthcare) and growth assets (data centres, renewable development). Long-term contracts provide downside protection
macro_factors.interest_rate_sensitivity: High - both direct (debt costs) and indirect (valuation multiples compress with higher discount rates). Infratil targeting operating cash flow to cover dividends reduces reliance on capital markets
macro_factors.currency_exposure: Significant - approximately 65% of portfolio value in offshore assets (AUD, USD, EUR). NZD appreciation headwind, depreciation tailwind
key_input_costs: Construction materials (steel, concrete for development projects)

recent_developments.event: Announced sale of 20% Fortysouth stake for >NZ$200m and legacy property for NZ$55m, bringing divestment program to 58% of NZ$1bn target
CDC announced 140MW of new contracts including 40MW Firmus/NVIDIA partnership and expansion to Perth with 200MW data centre. Reaffirmed target to double FY25 EBITDAF by FY27
Acquired additional 4.92% stake in Contact Energy for NZ$438m, increasing ownership to 14.3%. Funded with debt and new Infratil shares
Announced strategic review of Qscan (57% stake valued at NZ$487m) as part of portfolio simplification. Infratil Investor Day outlined three-pillar strategy and strategic KPIs
Longroad Energy announced financial close of 1,000 Mile solar project (400MW) to provide renewable energy to Meta data centres in Texas
Announced sale of 50% RetireAustralia stake for NZ$331m to Invesco Real Estate, expected to complete by end 2025
Added to S&P/ASX 200 Index, enhancing visibility with Australian institutional investors. Australian ownership now >10%
Contact Energy completed acquisition of Manawa Energy from Infratil (51% stake). Infratil received NZ$186m cash and shares, increasing Contact ownership to 9.4%
Reported FY2025 results: Proportionate EBITDAF NZ$986m (up 8.6%), net parent loss NZ$286m (vs NZ$770m profit in FY24 due to lower revaluations). 10-year TSR 17.0% p.a.
Completed NZ$1,275m equity raise (largest in NZ corporate history) to fund CDC growth. Injected A$434m into CDC alongside partner contributions
Acquired additional 1.58% CDC stake in competitive auction process, increasing ownership to 49.8% (now 51% post-FY25). Valuation 30%+ above prior independent valuation
Acquired remaining 49.95% of One NZ from Brookfield for NZ$1.8bn, bringing ownership to 99.9%. Now 100% locally owned and managed

items.notes: Originally NZ$1,000-1,050m on like-for-like basis excluding Manawa. Revised down to reflect RetireAustralia and Fortysouth divestments. Implies 9% growth on like-for-like basis vs FY2025
Relates to renewable development businesses (Gurin Energy, Galileo, Mint Renewables) investing in early-stage development. Originally NZ$85-105m loss
CDC and Longroad account for 69% of capex. Major programs: CDC capacity expansion, Longroad construction, Contact/Manawa integration projects
Additional equity injection into CDC alongside partner contributions to fund capacity expansion and contract deliveries. CDC targeting to double FY25 EBITDAF by FY27
Funding Longroad's build program. Longroad targeting growth from 3.5GW to 10GW operating capacity by 2028
Portfolio simplification program. 58% complete with RetireAustralia (NZ$331m), Fortysouth (>NZ$200m), property (NZ$55m) sales announced. Qscan under strategic review

items.target: Distributions to cover fixed costs and dividends
items.notes: Pillar 1 distributions expected to cover annual fixed outgoings and dividends as CDC/Longroad build programs complete and One NZ free cash flow grows

guidance.management_commentary: Chair Alison Gerry and CEO Jason Boyes emphasize confidence in navigating market volatility through focus on quality assets in structural growth sectors. CDC demand remains robust with contract momentum. Portfolio evolution underway to simplify holdings and concentrate on scaling core platforms. Target inclusion in ASX 200 index within next year to broaden shareholder base

bull_case: AI-driven data centre supercycle - CDC perfectly positioned with 1,600MW future pipeline, strategic locations, power connectivity advantages. Contract announcements (140MW in one month) validate sustained demand. Could see multiple expansion if AI growth trajectory maintained

Unique convergence play - Only infrastructure investor with scale positions in both data centres (CDC, Kao Data) and renewables (Longroad, Contact, Gurin, Galileo). Synergies emerging (Longroad-Meta, renewable power for data centres) create competitive advantage and growth optionality

Portfolio rerating potential - Infratil portfolio NAV historically traded at discount to share price. Successful execution of NZ$1bn divestment program, ASX 200 inclusion, and offshore investor base expansion could narrow discount. Analyst consensus NZ$13.58 target implies 20%+ upside

Proven value creation track record - 30-year history, 18% annualized returns since inception, 17% over past 10 years vs 11-15% target. Morrison & Co's investment discipline, origination capability, and portfolio company value creation demonstrated through CDC, Longroad, Tilt (demerged), Canberra Data Centres

Free cash flow inflection approaching - CDC and Longroad build programs completing over 2-3 years shifts portfolio mix back to balanced cash generation/growth. One NZ free cash flow growing. Operating distributions expected to cover dividends, reducing equity dilution and enabling reinvestment in new opportunities

Structural tailwinds across all sectors - Multi-decade trends: digitization/AI (data centres), energy transition (renewables), aging populations (healthcare), infrastructure deficits (private capital). Not cyclical fads but fundamental reshaping of economy
bear_case: CDC concentration risk - 41% portfolio weight in single asset creates massive volatility exposure. AI bubble concerns valid - hyperscaler capex could slow, alternative compute models emerge, or oversupply develops. If CDC valuation disappoints, limited portfolio diversification to offset

New Zealand economic malaise - Persistent NZ recession would impact 35%+ of portfolio (One NZ pricing/churn, Wellington Airport domestic traffic, healthcare volumes). Limited near-term catalysts for NZ economy. Could see prolonged earnings pressure across multiple assets

Interest rate risk in higher-for-longer environment - NZ$2.2bn net debt plus portfolio company leverage. If rates stay elevated, refinancing costs increase, asset valuations compress (higher discount rates), and equity return targets harder to achieve. Infrastructure assets bond-like, suffer when rates high

Execution risks on massive capital programs - CDC A$250m injection, Longroad US$110m, Gurin's US$2-3bn Project Vanda. Single project/customer concentration risk. Development delays, cost overruns, or demand shortfalls could destroy value. Gurin project particularly complex and binary

Management fee drag on returns - Large incentive fee payment to Morrison (primarily CDC outperformance) reduces net shareholder returns. External management structure means fee leakage vs internally managed peers. Performance hurdles help but fees still material cost

Portfolio simplification challenge - NZ$1bn divestment target requires finding buyers at acceptable prices in challenging M&A market. Transactions taking 2-3 years. Risk of being forced seller or accepting discounts. Meanwhile capital tied up in sub-scale, lower-return assets
